_accidents.CI_OtherType: Recommunicated proper PPE and reporting procedures

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SITE HSE Policy



GB Biosciences LLC (GBB) is committed to providing a safe and healthy working environment for our employees, contractors and community, protecting the environment, and assuring the safe operations of our processes. GBB will meet or exceed Federal, State, and Local regulations and other legal requirements.



Facility Information

The GB Biosciences facility produces agricultural chemicals. The plant has three covered processes Isophthalonitrile (IPN), Chlorothalonil (CTL), and chlorine distribution. The CTL unit produces the fungicide active ingredient Chlorothalonil which goes into the trade name products Ultrex® and Bravo®. Chlorothalonil is a fungicide for bananas, potatoes, peanuts, turf and other crops.



The IPN is produced by reacting ammonia and meta-xylene in the presence of oxygen and a catalyst. Ammonia enters the plant by rail car or tank truck, and is stored in a 12,000 gallon storage tank. Meta-xylene enters the plant either by railcar or truck.



The CTL unit takes IPN reacts it in vapor phase with Chlorine in the presence of a catalyst to form Chlorothalonil. Technical CTL is sent to Syngenta formulation plants worldwide or formulated and packaged into finished product on-site.



The plant has a chlorine distribution process which provides liquid chlorine to the CTL unit. Chlorine liquid is received in 180,000 pound rail cars and transferred to the CTL unit via pipeline. The chlorine is vaporized in the CTL unit and fed into the process.



Prevention Program Level 3

In addition to complying with EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68), GB Biosciences is governed by OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (1910.119). There are two (2) regulated chemicals above the threshold quantity; ammonia and chlorine. GB Biosciences has identified three covered processes; IPN process, CTL process, and chlorine distribution. 



Process hazard analyses (PHA) were performed for each covered unit. On a five year interval, the unit

PHAs are re-validated and updated including incidents and changes which have occurred in the previous 5-years.. 



Process changes are subject to a comprehensive management of change (MOC) program. As required, these changes undergo an appropriate approval and hazard review. 



The equipment for each area has been screened to determine if it can result in a catastrophic release to the environment. This equipment has been classified as PSM covered. This equipment is inspected on a frequency determined internally, based on past performance and risk. Any problems found during the inspections are repaired in a timely manner. 



There are operating procedures for each unit. These procedures are reviewed and certified on an annual basis. GB Biosciences has developed computer based training (CBT) for each procedure. Individuals affected by a procedure must perform a CBT for that procedure and pass a subsequent written test once per year. Training records are kept of this activity.



All incidents are investigated to determine root cause and measures to prevent recurrence.



Prevention Program Level 2

The facility has no program level 2 processes.



Accident History

Over the past 5 years, the facility has experienced 1 accidental release that met the RMP

reporting criteria threshold. 



Emergency Response

The Greens Bayou site has a 24 hour emergency response system in place. The site operates under an Incident Command System (ICS) for all emergencies. GB Biosciences has personnel on site trained to respond to fires, hazardous material releases, medical needs, and rescue situations 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Quarterly training and regular drills are received by all emergency responders. GB Biosciences is a member of the Channel Industries Mutual Aid organization (CIMA). CIMA is one of the largest mutual aid organizations offering emergency response assistance to member companies. GB Biosciences participates in annual functional emergency response drills a

nd training days with CIMA.



Additionally, GB Biosciences has representation on the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the local Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER) group. Both of these groups include the local fire department, sheriff's department, Harris County Office of Emergency Management ambulance services, local hospital, neighboring industries and business owners.



GB Biosciences utilizes a computer driven voice message alarm system to communicate to the plant population the type and location of an emergency. Critical plant personnel are also equipped with portable radios to aid in communications during an emergency. Radios are also in place for instant communications with neighboring industries and other CIMA members. 



GB Biosciences has its own internal fire water system with backup water supply. IPN and sections of CTL have fixed fire water deluge systems installed and a series of perimeter fixed fire monitors exists throughout the site. The ammonia railcar is also equipped with a water curtain.



The plant has three fixed chlorine monitoring systems: a series of fixed chlorine monitors throughout the CTL unit, a series of fixed chlorine monitors at the chlorine unloading stations, and a chlorine detection and shut off for the Heating, Venting and Air Conditioning systems to occupied buildings. In the event of a leak, an alarm in the CTL control room is activated. 



Changes to Improve Safety:

In the last 5-years, GBB has installed the following safety improvements: 



New Honeywell Experion Distributed Control Systems (DCSs) at all units to improve the reliability of basic control.  



Two Honeywell Safety Manager SIL 2 rated independent control logic systems for the safety shutdown interlocks were installed at IPN and Chlorine unloading.  Installation of a Honeywell Safety manager is scheduled for the CTL unit within the next 2 years. 



The controls and shutdown systems on the two Heat transfer furnaces was upgrade

d in 2015.  



GBB also has plans to install upgraded control system on the IPN incinerator in 2017
